questions.q: What would be the best way to implement a login feature using a REST API?

a.option: Create a POST: /login request that receives user:password and open a session in the API when is called, from that moment all requests are considered part of the same login session

Create a POST: /login requests that receives user:password and return a hash that lasts for X amount of time, that hash will have to be appended on every single request to be considered as part of the same session
Any approach is equally valid

questions.q: Why do we need to serialize stuff?

a.option: Because objects are to be to be sent as objects
Because the only wat to send information is to transform it into text
Because is a best practice in any RESTful API
Because we are told to do so, and we should follow without questioning

questions.q: When building an API, when is the best moment to serialize?

a.option: Right before sending back our response
Right after receiving the request
Whenever we are about to save the information into the database
There is no right time, it depends on every developer

questions.q: Based on the REST best practices, what is this API request for? POST: /author/204/album/3

a.option: To create a new album with the id 3, for the author with the id 204
To update the album with the id 3 made by the author with the id 204
To set the user 204 as author of the album 3
It can be use for any of the above options
Making the API clients send a hash signature on every request to validate their session
Forcing all API clients to autenticate on every request with username and password
Forcing the API clients to login in on the first request and keeping a session open for that client for a certain period of time.
